docs.title: Interactive Course Portal
docs.text: Welcome to your complete physics learning environment. Explore modules, practice problems, simulations, and reviews — all in one place.

docs.title: 🚀 Start Here
docs.text: - :rocket: **Begin Learning**    ---   Start with the fundamentals of 1D and 2D motion using calculus.    [Start Week 1 →](week1/index.md)  - :book: **View Syllabus**    ---   Course structure, grading, expectations, and weekly schedule.    [Open Syllabus →](syllabus.md)  - :mag: **Search the Course**    ---   Instantly find any formula, example, or topic using the search bar.    Use the 🔍 icon in the top-right.

docs.title: 📘 Course Modules
docs.text: - :one: **Week 1 — Kinematics**    ---   Motion in 1D, derivatives, integrals, free fall, displacement, velocity, acceleration.    [Go to Week 1 →](week1/index.md)  - :two: **Week 2 — Vectors & 2D Motion**    ---   Components, unit vectors, dot product, projectile motion, circular motion.    [Go to Week 2 →](week2/index.md)  - :three: **Week 3 — Forces & Newton’s Laws**    ---   Dynamics, free-body diagrams, friction, tension, Newton’s laws, applications.    [Go to Week 3 →](week3/index.md)  - :four: **Week 4 — Work & Energy**    ---   Work-energy theorem, kinetic & potential energy, conservative vs. non-conservative forces.    [Go to Week 4 →](week4/index.md)  - :five: **Week 5 — Momentum & Collisions**    ---   Impulse-momentum theorem, elastic/inelastic collisions, center of mass.    [Go to Week 5 →](week5/index.md)  - :six: **Week 6 — Rotational Motion**    ---   Rotational kinematics & dynamics, torque, moment of inertia.    [Go to Week 6 →](week6/index.md)  - :seven: **Week 7 — SHM & Gravitation**    ---   Springs, pendulums, oscillations, universal gravitation, orbital motion.    [Go to Week 7 →](week7/index.md)  - :eight: **Week 8 — Thermodynamics**    ---   Temperature, heat transfer, ideal gases, first law of thermodynamics.    [Go to Week 8 →](week8/index.md)

docs.title: 🧪 Interactive Tools

docs.title: 🧩 About the Course
docs.text:
This course combines physics + calculus to help you master:

  • motion in 1D & 2D
  • forces & Newton’s laws
  • rotational dynamics
  • energy & momentum
  • oscillations & waves
  • thermodynamics

You will learn to: - model physical systems - solve problems using derivatives & integrals - build intuition with diagrams & graphs - analyze real-world phenomena

# 🎉 Ready to Begin? [Start Week 1 →](week1/index.md){ .md-button .md-button--primary .md-button--large }

docs.title: Syllabus
docs.text: Content coming soon.

docs.title: 🧭 Week 1 — Units, Dimensions & 1D Motion (Illustrated, Tiered Mastery)
docs.text:
Welcome to Week 1 of College Physics 201.

This module is designed so that a motivated student can teach themselves the Week 1 material using:

  • Illustrated explanations
  • Tiered mastery (core → deeper → advanced)
  • Examples and practice with hidden solutions
  • Graphs and diagrams from your lecture slides (Ch. 1 & Ch. 3)
0. How to Use This Page Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application
  • Each section is collapsible — click the bar to expand it.
  • Inside most sections you’ll see tabs:
  • Core Idea — what you must know
  • Deeper Reasoning — why it works and how to think about it

  • Advanced Application — calculus, graphs, and more challenging thinking

  • Many problems have hidden solutions. Try them before opening the answer.

Learning physics is like building a mental model of how the universe behaves. This page is structured so you can: - get the big picture first - then drill into detail only when you’re ready - then test yourself

As you go through, ask yourself: - “Where would this show up in real life?” - “Could I explain this to someone else?” - “What equation or graph represents this situation?”

1. Physical Quantities, Units, and Measurement Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application

Physics describes the world using measurable quantities: - length, time, mass, temperature, etc. - each must have a unit (meters, seconds, kilograms, kelvins…)

We use the SI (International System of Units) as a common language.

Quantity Unit Symbol Length meter m Mass kilogram kg Time second s Temperature kelvin K Electric current ampere A

Visual from your slides:

A “number” without a unit is meaningless in physics.

Compare: - “The car went 30” → 30 what? - “The car went 30 m” vs “30 mi” vs “30 km” → very different physical situations.

Units also hide physical scales: - meters vs nanometers vs light-years - seconds vs microseconds vs years

Your slide likely showing different scales:

This helps students see that the same laws apply from atoms to galaxies.

When you later do more advanced physics (EM, quantum, thermo), being sloppy with units leads to: - wrong answers - confusion about what an equation actually means - difficulty catching mistakes

Habit to build now: - Always write the unit next to your answer. - Always check if unit types “match” on both sides of equations.

2. SI Prefixes and Unit Conversions (Factor–Label Method) Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application

We use prefixes to handle very large or small numbers:

Prefix Symbol Factor kilo k \(10^3\) mega M \(10^6\) giga G \(10^9\) milli m \(10^{-3}\) micro μ \(10^{-6}\) nano n \(10^{-9}\)

From your slides:

We do conversions using the factor–label method (multiplying by 1 cleverly).

Example: Convert 60 mph to m/s

\[ 60\ \frac{\text{mi}}{\text{hr}} \cdot \frac{1609\ \text{m}}{1\ \text{mi}} \cdot \frac{1\ \text{hr}}{3600\ \text{s}} = 26.8\ \text{m/s} \]

Each “conversion factor” is just a fancy version of:

\[ \frac{\text{same quantity in different units}}{\text{same quantity in original units}} = 1 \]

So we are multiplying by 1, but in a way that changes units.

In more advanced problems, you might convert: - km/h to m/s - g/cm\(^3\) to kg/m\(^3\) - J to eV (electron-volts)

Practice problem:

Convert \( 3.5\ \text{g/cm}^3 \) into kg/m\(^3\).

Show Solution \[ 3.5\ \frac{\text{g}}{\text{cm}^3} \cdot \frac{1\ \text{kg}}{1000\ \text{g}} \cdot \left(\frac{100\ \text{cm}}{1\ \text{m}}\right)^3 = 3.5 \cdot \frac{1}{1000} \cdot (10^6) = 3500\ \frac{\text{kg}}{\text{m}^3} \] 3. Dimensions and Dimensional Analysis Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application

Dimensions represent the type of quantity, not the unit.

  • Length: \([L]\)
  • Time: \([T]\)
  • Mass: \([M]\)

Examples: [ \text{Velocity} : [L][T^{-1}] ] [ \text{Acceleration} : [L][T^{-2}] ] [ \text{Force} : [M][L][T^{-2}] ]

You can use dimensions to check if an equation could possibly be correct.

Suppose someone proposes:

\[ v = 3t + 7x \]
  • Left-hand side: \(v \rightarrow [L/T]\)
  • Right-hand side:
  • \(3t \rightarrow [T]\)
  • \(7x \rightarrow [L]\)

You cannot add \([T]\) and \([L]\). Therefore, the equation is nonsense physically.

Dimensional analysis doesn’t prove an equation is right, but it can tell you if it’s definitely wrong.

Often, we know: - the relevant quantities (e.g., \(g\), \(h\), \(v_0\)), and - the dimension we want (e.g., time [T])

Dimensional analysis can guide us to plausible forms of relationships.

It’s also very helpful in checking your work in exams.

Visual from your slides:

4. Position and Displacement Along a Line Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application

Position \(x(t)\) tells you where an object is along a 1D axis. Displacement is the change in position:

\[ \Delta x = x_f - x_i \]

It can be positive (forward), negative (backwards) or zero.

From your Ch. 3 slides:

Position depends on your choice of origin. If you choose \(x=0\) at one place vs another, the numeric values change, but physics does not.

Displacement cares only about start and end, not the path taken.

If \(x(t)\) is given as a function (e.g., a polynomial), we can: - compute displacement over a time interval: \(x(t_2)-x(t_1)\) - compute average velocity: \(\frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}\)

Example:

[ x(t) = 2t^2 - 4t + 1 ] From \(t=1\) to \(t=3\):

\[ \Delta x = x(3)-x(1) \] Show Solution

[ x(3)=2(9)-4(3)+1=18-12+1=7 ] [ x(1)=2(1)-4(1)+1=2-4+1=-1 ] [ \Delta x = 7 - (-1) = 8\ \text{m} ]

5. Average vs Instantaneous Velocity Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application

Average velocity over a time interval:

\[ \bar{v} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} \]

Instantaneous velocity is the velocity at one instant:

\[ v(t) = \frac{dx}{dt} \]

On a position–time graph: - average velocity ↔ slope of a secant line - instantaneous velocity ↔ slope of the tangent line

From your slides:

Average velocity is like “overall change”: “From 1:00 to 1:05, my position changed by 500 m, so on average I moved 100 m/min.”

Instantaneous velocity zooms in on one time: “Exactly at 1:02:30, what was my speed and direction?”

Conceptual graph from your slides:

Given: [ x(t) = t^3 - 4t + 2 ]

  • Average velocity from \(t=1\) to \(t=2\)
  • Instantaneous velocity at \(t=1\)
Show Solution \[ v(t) = \frac{dx}{dt} = 3t^2 - 4 \]

Average from 1 to 2:

[ x(2) = 8 - 8 + 2 = 2 ] [ x(1) = 1 - 4 + 2 = -1 ] [ \bar{v} = \frac{2 - (-1)}{2-1} = 3\ \text{m/s} ]

Instantaneous at \(t=1\):

\[ v(1) = 3(1)^2-4 = -1\ \text{m/s} \]

Negative means motion is in the negative direction at that instant.

6. Acceleration: Changing Velocity Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application

Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity:

\[ a(t) = \frac{dv}{dt} \]

On a velocity–time graph: - the slope is the acceleration

Slide illustration:

There are several ways velocity can change: - speed increases - speed decreases - direction reverses

All of these involve acceleration, even if the speed is momentarily zero.

For constant acceleration: [ a = \text{constant} \Rightarrow v(t) = v_0 + at,\quad x(t) = x_0 + v_0 t + \frac{1}{2}at^2 ]

Suppose: [ a(t) = 6t,\quad v(0) = 3,\quad x(0)=0 ]

Then: [ v(t) = \int 6t\,dt = 3t^2 + C ]

Using \(v(0)=3\): [ 3(0)^2 + C = 3 \Rightarrow C = 3 ]

\[ v(t) = 3t^2+3 \]

Then: [ x(t) = \int (3t^2+3)\,dt = t^3 + 3t + C_2 ]

Using \(x(0)=0\) gives \(C_2=0\).

\[ x(t) = t^3 + 3t \] 7. Free Fall & Constant Acceleration (1D Kinematics) Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application

Near Earth’s surface, ignoring air resistance:

\[ a = g \approx 9.8\ \text{m/s}^2 \quad (\text{downward}) \]

If we take upward as positive, then:

\[ a = -g \]

Kinematic equations (constant acceleration):

[ v = v_0 + at ] [ x = x_0 + v_0 t + \frac{1}{2}at^2 ] [ v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a(x - x_0) ]

Your slide visual:

Free fall includes: - dropping an object (\(v_0 = 0\)) - throwing an object upward - throwing an object downward

All share: - same acceleration magnitude (if air resistance is negligible) - parabolic position–time graphs - linear velocity–time graphs

Example — Dropped from 20 m

\[ x_0 = 20\ \text{m},\quad v_0 = 0,\quad a=-9.8\ \text{m/s}^2 \]

Position:

\[ x(t) = 20 + 0\cdot t + \frac{1}{2}(-9.8)t^2 = 20 - 4.9 t^2 \]

Time to hit the ground: set \(x(t)=0\):

\[ 20 - 4.9t^2 = 0 \Rightarrow t^2=\frac{20}{4.9} \Rightarrow t \approx 2.02\ \text{s} \]

Velocity on impact:

\[ v = v_0 + at = -9.8(2.02) \approx -19.8\ \text{m/s} \]

Negative indicates downward direction.

8. Worked Examples (Tiered) Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application

Example 1 — From Position to Velocity and Acceleration

\[ x(t) = 4t^3 - 2t \] \[ v(t) = 12t^2 - 2 \] \[ a(t) = 24t \]

Graph-style slide:

  • Position is cubic → velocity quadratic → acceleration linear.
  • As time increases:
  • velocity grows faster
  • acceleration keeps changing (not constant)

Example 2 — Car Accelerating from Rest

A car starts from rest and accelerates at \(4\ \text{m/s}^2\) for 5 s.

\[ v = v_0 + at = 0 + 4(5) = 20\ \text{m/s} \] \[ x = x_0 + v_0 t + \frac{1}{2}at^2 = 0 + 0 + \frac{1}{2}(4)(25) = 50\ \text{m} \]

Example 3 — Free-Fall Upward Throw

A ball is thrown upward at \(12\ \text{m/s}\). Maximum height (using \(v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a\Delta x\) with final \(v=0\)):

\[ 0 = (12)^2 + 2(-9.8)\Delta x \Rightarrow \Delta x = \frac{144}{19.6} \approx 7.35\ \text{m} \] 9. Practice Problems (Try First, Then Expand) Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application & Solutions
  1. Given \(x(t)=2t^3 - 5t^2 + 7\), find \(v(t)\) and \(a(t)\).
  2. A car accelerates from rest at \(4\ \text{m/s}^2\) for 5 s. Find distance traveled.
  3. A ball is thrown upward at \(12\ \text{m/s}\). Find max height.
  4. Convert 45 mph to m/s.
  5. If \(v(t)=6t\) and \(x(0)=0\), find \(x(t)\).

Think for each: - What is given? (position? velocity? acceleration?) - Do I need a derivative or integral? - Is this constant acceleration?

Problem 1 Solution

[ x(t)=2t^3 - 5t^2 + 7 ] [ v(t)=\frac{dx}{dt}=6t^2 - 10t ] [ a(t)=\frac{dv}{dt}=12t - 10 ]

Problem 2 Solution \[ x = \frac{1}{2}at^2 = \frac{1}{2}(4)(25)=50\ \text{m} \] Problem 3 Solution \[ h = \frac{v_0^2}{2g} = \frac{144}{19.6} \approx 7.35\ \text{m} \] Problem 4 Solution \[ 45\ \text{mph} \approx 20.1\ \text{m/s} \] Problem 5 Solution

[ v(t)=6t \Rightarrow x(t)=\int 6t\,dt = 3t^2 + C ] Using \(x(0)=0\) gives \(C=0\). Thus: [ x(t)=3t^2 ]

10. Summary Sheet (Exam-Focused) Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application

Definitions

\[ v(t)=\frac{dx}{dt} \qquad a(t)=\frac{dv}{dt} \]

Constant-Acceleration Equations

[ v = v_0 + at ] [ x = x_0 + v_0 t + \frac{1}{2}at^2 ] [ v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a(x-x_0) ]

Key Ideas

  • Units & dimensions must be consistent.
  • Derivative ↔ slope of graph.
  • Integral ↔ area under graph.
  • Free fall ≈ constant acceleration due to gravity.

Ask yourself if you can: - explain what each symbol means physically - sketch a rough graph for each motion situation - decide which equation to use based on what’s known

On a test, the hardest problems often combine: - reading a graph - interpreting a word problem - choosing a kinematic equation - performing a unit conversion - checking units/dimensions at the end

Practice spotting all of these elements in a single problem.

docs.title: (Fully Illustrated — Tiered Mastery Edition)
docs.text:
This module teaches you everything you need about vectors, components, 2D motion, projectiles, and relative velocity — even if you missed class. Every section includes:

  • Core Idea (must-know)
  • Deeper Reasoning (why it works)
  • Advanced Application (real physics + calculus)
  • Illustrations from your textbook
  • Concept Checks
  • Examples & Practice

docs.title: ⭐ 0. HOW TO USE THIS MODULE
docs.text: Click to expand

docs.title: What this module gives you:
docs.text:
• Complete lesson on Vectors + 2D Motion
  • Diagrams from your uploaded Chapters 2 and 4
  • Beginner-friendly explanations
  • Practice with hidden answers
  • Scaffolding from intuition → mastery

docs.title: How to learn efficiently:
docs.text:
• Expand each collapsible section
  • Do concept checks BEFORE revealing solutions
  • Work practice problems on paper first
  • Review the summary sheet before the quiz

docs.title: ⭐ 1. WHAT IS A VECTOR?
docs.text:
1.1 Understanding Vectors (Core → Deeper → Advanced) Core Idea

A vector has both: - magnitude (how much) - direction (which way)

Common vectors: - displacement - velocity - acceleration - force

Deeper Reasoning

Scalars answer “how much?”. Vectors answer “how much + which direction?” — direction changes physics.

A 10 N push north ≠ a 10 N push east.

Advanced Application

Component form:

\[ \vec{A} = \langle A_x, A_y \rangle \]

Unit vector form:

\[ \vec{A} = A_x\hat{i} + A_y\hat{j} \]

Magnitude:

\[ |\vec{A}|=\sqrt{A_x^2 + A_y^2} \]

Direction:

\[ \theta = \tan^{-1}\left(\frac{A_y}{A_x}\right) \]

docs.title: ⭐ 2. WHY VECTOR COMPONENTS MATTER
docs.text:
2.1 Components (Core → Deeper → Advanced) Core Idea

Any vector can be broken into horizontal and vertical parts:

\[ A_x = A\cos\theta,\qquad A_y = A\sin\theta \]

Deeper Reasoning

The key idea:

A 2D motion problem is really just two separate 1D problems happening at the same time.

  • Gravity affects only vertical motion
  • Horizontal motion is independent
  • Calculus and kinematics become easy in components
Advanced Application

Example:

A \(12\text{ m}\) vector at \(60^\circ\):

\[ A_x=12\cos60^\circ=6 \] \[ A_y=12\sin60^\circ=10.39 \]

docs.title: ⭐ 3. VECTOR ADDITION & SUBTRACTION
docs.text:
3.1 Adding and Subtracting Vectors Core Idea

Add vectors component-wise:

\[ \vec{A}+\vec{B}=\langle A_x+B_x,\ A_y+B_y\rangle \]

Geometric version (tip-to-tail):

Deeper Reasoning

The geometric and algebraic methods give identical results.

Subtraction:

\[ \vec{A}-\vec{B}=\vec{A}+(-\vec{B}) \] Advanced Application

Example:

\[ \vec{A}=\langle 3,4\rangle,\quad \vec{B}=\langle -2,5\rangle \] \[ \vec{A}+\vec{B}=\langle 1,9\rangle \]

docs.title: ⭐ 4. DOT PRODUCT (MEASURES ALIGNMENT)
docs.text:
4.1 Dot Product (Core → Deeper → Advanced) Core Idea

Component definition:

\[ \vec{A}\cdot\vec{B}=A_xB_x + A_yB_y \]

Geometric definition:

\[ \vec{A}\cdot\vec{B}=|\vec{A}||\vec{B}|\cos\theta \]

Deeper Reasoning

Dot product tells you how aligned two vectors are:

  • positive → same direction
  • zero → perpendicular
  • negative → opposite
Advanced Application

Angle between vectors:

\[ \theta = \cos^{-1}\left(\frac{\vec{A}\cdot\vec{B}}{|\vec{A}||\vec{B}|}\right) \]

docs.title: ⭐ 5. MOTION IN TWO DIMENSIONS
docs.text:
5.1 Independence of x- and y-motion Core Idea

Key principle:

  • Horizontal and vertical motions are independent
  • Time links them
  • Gravity affects only vertical direction

\[ a_x=0,\qquad a_y=-g \] Deeper Reasoning

Physics becomes simple when you realize:

  • The x-motion behaves like constant velocity
  • The y-motion behaves like free fall
  • Combine the motions → you get a parabola
Advanced Application

Break initial velocity into components:

\[ v_{0x}=v_0\cos\theta \] \[ v_{0y}=v_0\sin\theta \]

docs.title: ⭐ 6. PROJECTILE MOTION
docs.text:
6.1 Full Projectile Motion Model Core Idea

Horizontal motion:

\[ x(t)=v_{0x}t \]

Vertical motion:

\[ y(t)=y_0 + v_{0y}t - \frac{1}{2}gt^2 \]

Deeper Reasoning

The path is a parabola because:

  • Horizontal: constant velocity
  • Vertical: constant acceleration

Eliminating \(t\) gives:

\[ y = x \tan\theta - \frac{g}{2v_0^2\cos^2\theta}\,x^2 \] Advanced Application

Time of flight:

\[ T=\frac{2v_{0y}}{g} \]

Range:

\[ R = \frac{v_0^2\sin(2\theta)}{g} \]

Maximum height:

\[ h_{\max} = \frac{v_{0y}^2}{2g} \]

docs.title: ⭐ 7. RELATIVE VELOCITY
docs.text:
7.1 Motion from Different Reference Frames Core Idea

Relative velocity formula:

\[ \vec{v}_{A/B}=\vec{v}_A - \vec{v}_B \]

Deeper Reasoning

Situations using relative velocity:

  • boats in current
  • planes in wind
  • cars passing
  • walking on a moving walkway
Advanced Application

Example:

Plane: \(80\text{ m/s}\) north Wind: \(30\text{ m/s}\) east

\[ \vec{v}=\langle 30,\ 80\rangle \] \[ |\vec{v}|=\sqrt{30^2+80^2}=85.4\text{ m/s} \]

docs.title: ⭐ 8. WORKED EXAMPLES
docs.text:
Example 1 — Vector Components

10 m vector at 30°:

\[ A_x=10\cos30^\circ=8.66 \] \[ A_y=10\sin30^\circ=5 \]

Example 2 — Projectile Launched at Angle

Launch at 20 m/s, 40°:

\[ v_{0x} = 20\cos40^\circ \] \[ v_{0y} = 20\sin40^\circ \]

Example 3 — Relative Velocity

Car A: 30 m/s east Car B: 20 m/s west

\[ \vec{v}_{A/B}=\langle30,0\rangle - \langle -20,0\rangle \] \[ \vec{v}_{A/B}=\langle50,0\rangle \]

docs.title: ⭐ 9. PRACTICE PROBLEMS
docs.text:
Try these before revealing answers

1. Components of a 25 m vector at 53°. 2. Launch at 15 m/s, 30°. Find flight time. 3. Boat east 4 m/s, current north 3 m/s. Resultant speed? 4. \(\vec{A}=\langle2,3\rangle\), \(\vec{B}=\langle-1,4\rangle\). Find \(\vec{A}+\vec{B}\). 5. Ball thrown horizontally at 8 m/s from 12 m high. Range?

Solutions

  1. [ A_x=25\cos53^\circ\approx15 ] [ A_y=25\sin53^\circ\approx20 ]

  2. \[ T=\frac{2v_{0y}}{g}=\frac{2(15\sin30^\circ)}{9.8}=1.53\text{ s} \]
  3. \[ |\vec{v}|=\sqrt{4^2+3^2}=5\text{ m/s} \]
  4. \[ \langle2,3\rangle+\langle-1,4\rangle=\langle1,7\rangle \]

  5. [ t=\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}=\sqrt{\frac{24}{9.8}}=1.56\text{ s} ] [ x=vt=8(1.56)=12.5\text{ m} ]

docs.title: ⭐ 10. SUMMARY SHEET (Exam Essentials)
docs.text: \[ A_x = A\cos\theta,\quad A_y = A\sin\theta \] \[ x(t)=v_{0x}t \] \[ y(t)=y_0 + v_{0y}t - \frac{1}{2}gt^2 \] \[ R=\frac{v_0^2\sin2\theta}{g} \] \[ \vec{v}_{A/B}=\vec{v}_A - \vec{v}_B \]

docs.title: Understanding Rotation Through What You Already Know
docs.text: Rotational motion is one of the hardest topics in physics — not because the ideas are new, but because the language changes. This module rewrites everything using what you already understand from Weeks 1–6.

docs.title: ⭐ 1. Rotational Motion & Linear Motion: The Master Connection
1.1 Why Rotation Feels Hard — and Why It Shouldn’t
docs.text:
Linear → Rotational Analogy (The Foundation) Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application

Rotational motion is just linear motion wrapped into a circle.

Every linear quantity has a rotational partner:

Linear Rotational Meaning \(x\) \(\theta\) Position (angle) \(v\) \(\omega\) Velocity \(a\) \(\alpha\) Acceleration \(m\) \(I\) Resistance to motion \(F\) \(\tau\) Cause of acceleration \(p = mv\) \(L = I\omega\) Momentum \(K = \tfrac12 mv^2\) \(K = \tfrac12 I\omega^2\) Kinetic energy

Understanding this chart makes everything else easier.

Rotation inherits the mathematics of linear motion: - Derivatives describe change - Integrals accumulate change - Forces (or torques) cause acceleration - Mass (or inertia) resists acceleration

The physics does not change — only the geometry and terminology do.

This is why you can rely on Weeks 1–6 such as: - Kinematics - Free-body diagrams - Energy - Momentum

Rotation is simply those ideas in circular form.

Total relationships:

\[ \omega = \frac{d\theta}{dt}, \qquad \alpha = \frac{d\omega}{dt} \]

Constant acceleration gives rotational kinematic equations:

[ \omega = \omega_0 + \alpha t ] [ \theta = \theta_0 + \omega_0 t + \tfrac12\alpha t^2 ] [ \omega^2 = \omega_0^2 + 2\alpha(\theta-\theta_0) ]

docs.title: 2.1 What “Angle” Really Represents
docs.text:
Understanding θ, ω, α Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application
  • Angular position (θ): where the object is on a circle
  • Angular velocity (ω): how fast the angle changes
  • Angular acceleration (α): how fast ω changes

These three values behave exactly like: - position → \(x(t)\) - velocity → \(v(t) = \frac{dx}{dt}\) - acceleration → \(a(t) = \frac{dv}{dt}\)

The only difference is: - Angle measures rotation, not distance.

But calculus works the same.

Connecting linear & rotational motion:

\[ s = r\theta \]

The arc length \(s\) is a linear displacement across the circle.

Tangential velocity: [ v = r\omega ]

Tangential acceleration: [ a_t = r\alpha ]

Centripetal acceleration: [ a_c = \omega^2 r ]

docs.title: ⭐ 3. Torque — The Rotational Equivalent of Force
3.1 Why Force Alone Cannot Tell You How Something Rotates
docs.text:
Torque (τ): The Cause of Angular Acceleration Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application

Torque tells you how effectively a force creates rotation.

\[ \tau = rF_\perp \]
  • \(r\): distance from pivot
  • \(F_\perp\): the perpendicular component of the force

Why the angle matters:

  • Pulling perpendicular → maximum torque
  • Pulling at an angle → less torque
  • Pulling directly toward pivot → zero torque

Perpendicular force: [ F_\perp = F\sin\theta ]

So torque is: [ \tau = rF\sin\theta ]

Right-Hand Rule (simplified): - Curl fingers from \(r\) → \(F\) - Thumb direction = torque direction - Out of page: counterclockwise (+) - Into page: clockwise (–)

docs.title: ⭐ 4. Moment of Inertia (I): How Hard It Is to Rotate Something
4.1 The Rotational Version of “Mass”
docs.text:
Moment of Inertia (I) Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application \[ I = \sum mr^2 \]

Mass far from the axis contributes a lot to \(I\). Mass near the axis contributes little.

Students struggle because inertia feels abstract. Here's the intuition:

  • A baseball bat is easier to swing when held near the thick end (mass closer → smaller I)
  • A skater spins faster with arms in (decreasing r decreases I)

Distribution matters more than total mass.

Parallel Axis Theorem

\[ I = I_{\text{cm}} + md^2 \]

Used whenever the pivot is not at the center of mass.

docs.title: 5.1 The Torque Version of F = ma
docs.text:
τ = Iα Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application \[ \tau_{\text{net}} = I\alpha \]

Torque causes angular acceleration in the same way force causes linear acceleration.

To solve rotational problems: 1. Draw free-body diagram 2. Choose pivot 3. Determine which forces cause torque 4. Assign torque signs 5. Apply \(\sum \tau = I\alpha\)

Critical reminders: - Only perpendicular force counts - Torques have signs (CW / CCW matter)

Pulley systems often require:

[ Tr = I\alpha ] and [ a = r\alpha ]

Letting you link rotational + linear motion.

docs.title: 6.1 Why Wheels Don’t Slide (Most of the Time)
docs.text:
The Condition v = rω Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application

Rolling without slipping means:

  • Bottom point is instantaneously at rest
  • Wheel grips the ground
  • Linear & rotational motion are linked:
\[ v = r\omega \]

The wheel actually has three velocities:

  • Top: \(2v\)
  • Center: \(v\)
  • Bottom: \(0\)

Because rotational and translational motion add/subtract.

Total kinetic energy:

\[ K = \tfrac12 mv^2 + \tfrac12 I\omega^2 \]

Substitute \(v = r\omega\):

\[ K = \tfrac12 mv^2 + \tfrac12 I\left(\frac{v}{r}\right)^2 \]

docs.title: These are written step-by-step for mastery.
docs.text:
Example 1 — Torque from an Angled Force Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application

A 0.25 m wrench with a 120 N force applied at 90°:

\[ \tau = rF = (0.25)(120)=30\ \text{N·m} \]

If applied at 30°:

[ \tau = rF\sin30^\circ ] [ \tau = (0.25)(120)(0.5)=15\ \text{N·m} ]

If force is NOT applied at the end:

\[ \tau = (r_{\text{new}})F\sin\theta \]

Example 2 — Rolling Cylinder Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application

Cylinder: \(I = \tfrac12 mr^2\), moving at 4 m/s

\[ \omega = \frac{v}{r} \]

Total KE:

[ K = \tfrac12 mv^2 + \tfrac12 I\omega^2 ] [ = \tfrac12 mv^2 + \tfrac14 mv^2 = \tfrac34 mv^2 ]

Same method works for: - spheres - hoops - disks

Example 3 — Angular Acceleration from Torque Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application

Disk (2 kg, r=0.20 m), F_tan=10 N.

\[ \tau = rF = 2\ \text{N·m} \]

Moment of inertia:

\[ I = \tfrac12 mr^2 = 0.04 \] \[ \alpha = \frac{\tau}{I} = 50\ \text{rad/s}^2 \]

A tension-based pulley system follows the same pattern.

docs.title: ⭐ 8. Practice Problems (Hidden Solutions)
docs.text:
Try These First Core IdeaDeeper ReasoningAdvanced Application
  1. A 15 N force at 45° acts 0.40 m from pivot. Find torque.
  2. A disk rolls at 3 m/s. Find ω.
  3. A rod (2 kg, 1.2 m) pivots at end. Find I_end.
  4. A wheel accelerates from 2 to 8 rad/s in 3s. Find α.
  5. A 6 kg cylinder rolls at 5 m/s. Find total KE.

These cover: - torque - rolling motion - parallel axis theorem - rotational energy - angular acceleration

Solutions:

  1. \[ \tau = rF\sin\theta = (0.40)(15)(\sin45^\circ)=4.24 \]
  2. \[ \omega = \frac{v}{r} \]

  3. [ I_{\text{cm}} = \tfrac{1}{12}mL^2 = 0.24 ] [ I_{\text{end}} = I_{\text{cm}} + md^2 = 0.96 ]

  4. \[ \alpha = \frac{\Delta\omega}{t} = \frac{8-2}{3}=2 \]
  5. \[ K = \tfrac12 mv^2 + \tfrac12 I\omega^2 \]

docs.title: ⭐ 9. Summary Sheet (Exam Essentials)
docs.text: [ \tau = rF\sin\theta ] [ I = \sum mr^2 ] [ \tau = I\alpha ] [ v = r\omega ] [ a_t = r\alpha \qquad a_c = \omega^2 r ] [ K = \tfrac12 mv^2 + \tfrac12 I\omega^2 ]
